thread.title: Seven books that could become Oscar-nominated films

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Seven books that could become Oscar-nominated films
text:
Courtesy of Warner Bros. Pictures/Courtesy of Warner Bros. Picture Johnny Depp gives yet another career-defining performance as the notorious James "Whitey" Bulger in "Black Mass." It doesn’t usually take long before a biography or an autobiography is considered for a film.
And some biopics sometimes end up being nominated for several global awards, including what’s arguably the most prestigious of them all — the Academy Awards.
In 2013, the critically acclaimed movie, “12 Years a Slave,” won three Oscars for best picture, best actress in a supporting role and best writing adapted screenplay, marking its place in film history for African-American filmmakers and actors.
In 2014, Oscar winner Reese Witherspoon starred in the movie version of author Cheryl Strayed’s memoir, “Wild.”
The film and Reese’s performance welcomed a slew of award nominations from the Academy Awards, Golden Globes, BAFTA Awards, Screen Actor Guild Awards and the Writers Guild of America, to name a few.
Here is a handful of published books that have been or will soon be adapted into Oscar-worthy films.
“The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair that Changed America” by Erik Larson
Vintage Publishing "The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair That Changed America " describes the true story of murders that occurred behind the scenes of Chicago's World Fair during the late 1800s. Enlarge Michael Loccisano/Getty Images It is rumored that Leonardo DiCaprio will star in the film as Dr. H.H. Holmes, named as the murderer of close to 200 people at the World Fair. Enlarge "The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair That Changed America " describes the true story of murders that occurred behind the scenes of Chicago's World Fair during the late 1800s.
It is rumored that Leonardo DiCaprio will star in the film as Dr. H.H. Holmes, named as the murderer of close to 200 people at the World Fair.
In 1893, Chicago’s World Fair was an extraordinary attraction for millions of visitors seeking entertainment.
It’s where the Ferris wheel and Pabst Blue Ribbon beer were introduced to the world.
Chicago’s World Fair was also a home for mass murderer Dr. Henry Howard Holmes and his “ Murder Castle .”
Published in 2003, author Erik Larson’s New York Times bestseller “ The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair that Changed America ” details both the origins of the World Fair and Holmes’ killing spree.
Larson’s book will be adapted into a movie starring Leonardo DiCaprio and directed by Martin Scorsese.
“Black Mass: Whitey Bulger, the FBI, and a Devil’s Deal” by Dick Lehr and Gerard O’Neill
Courtesy of Warner Bros. Pictures/Courtesy of Warner Bros. Picture Early 2016 Oscar buzz has been doled out to "Black Mass" and Depp's role in the movie. Anthony Harvey/Getty Images Jessica Chastain will play the lead character of Antonina Zabinska in the movie, "The Zookeeper's Wife." Universal Pictures UK British actor Eddie Redmayne could win a second Oscar for his role of Lili Erbe/Einar Wegener in "The Danish Girl." Previous Next Enlarge Variety magazine says Johnny Depp as one of history’s most notorious gangsters, James “Whitey” Bulger, is the revered actor’s “ career-best work ” in the film “ Black Mass .”
The film, which debuted in theaters last month, is based on the book, “Black Mass: Whitey Bulger, the FBI, and a Devil’s Deal.”
The Boston Globe bestseller and film reveals the tale behind Bulger’s informant deal with childhood friend and FBI officer, John Connolly.
Depp is already gaining early Oscar buzz for his role as Bulger, as is the movie itself.
“The Zookeeper’s Wife: A War Story” by Diane Ackerman
Polish zookeepers Jan and Antonina Zabinski saved the lives of up to 300 Jewish people during German politician Adolf Hitler’s Nazi Party occupation, by housing them in animal cages and sheds in the Warsaw Zoo.
Diane Ackerman ’s epic World War II story is slated to arrive in theaters in 2016, starring Jessica Chastain and Daniel Brühl.
“The Minds of Billy Milligan” by Daniel Keyes
Mary Circelli/AP Billy Milligan (right) is believed to be the first person to use the diagnosis of Multiple-Personality Disorder as an insanity defense in a criminal trial. TIMOTHY A. CLARY/AFP/Getty Images Leonardo DiCaprio will produce a film about Milligan and star as the real-life character in the upcoming film, "The Minds of Billy Milligan." Simon & Schuster Susannah Cahalan wrote the memoir, "Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness," about her journey to being diagnosed and treated for a rare autoimmune disease. Jason Merritt/Getty Images Chloë Grace Moretz will portray Cahalan in the movie version of the writer's book. Previous Next Enlarge Billy Milligan was diagnosed with Multiple-Personality Disorder.
He was also placed in prison and arrested as a suspect of kidnapping, rape and armed robbery charges in the 1970s.
Milligan pled insanity in court, due to his 24 different personalities, and was ultimately sent to a number of mental hospitals.
Author Daniel Keyes wrote his biographical non-fiction novel — “The Minds of Billy Milligan” — about Milligan’s court case and mental health diagnosis, which is being produced as a major motion picture starring Leonardo DiCaprio.
“The Lost City of Z” by David Grann
Sunday Now Bookpage/Sherryl Connelly "The Lost City of Z" looks at the story of British explorer Percy Fawcett who never returned from his travels in the Amazon jungle in the early 1900s. “The Lost City of Z” chronicles British explorer Percy Fawcett’s expedition into the Amazon jungle’s “ Lost City of Z ” in 1925.
Fawcett never came back.
Grann’s nonfiction tale gives readers a peak into Fawcett’s Amazon travels, while attempting to explain Fawcett’s dissapearance.
The movie version of “The Lost City of Z” will portray “Sons of Anarchy” actor Charlie Hunnam as the doomed traveler and “Twilight” actor Robert Pattinson.
Photopress Belfast / Splash News/Photopress Belfast / Splash News Robert Pattinson will play the role of Henry Costin in "The Lost City of Z." “The Danish Girl” by David Ebershoff
Even though "The Danish Girl" will not be officially released in theaters until Nov., media pundits are predicting its star’s — British actor Eddie Redmayne — second Academy Award win and the film’s highly possible nomination for “Best Picture.”
“The Danish Girl” is “loosely inspired” by David Ebershoff’s book and the true love story between Danish transgendered woman Lili Erbe and her lover Gerda Wegener.
Eddie Redmayne stars in the film as Erbe and budding Swedish actress Alicia Vikander as Wegener.
“Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness” by Susannah Cahalan
Imagine waking up one day healthy at the age of 24, and then the next with symptoms of paranoia, hallucinations, and without the ability to move.
This happened to writer Susannah Cahalan .
After series of vague tests, she was finally diagnosed as having a “ brain on fire ,” which became the title of her memoir.
Cahalan’s story has been greenlit for a movie adaptation to star Chloë Grace Moretz as Cahalan.
